text.p: The following are leading domestic stories in Portuguese newspapers.

- Spain's Telefonica has taken a 3.5 percent stake in Portugal Telecom which gets 1.0 percent of the Spanish company. The agreement means that phone calls between Portugal and Spain will be be considered regional and not international.
- The state's current spending rose by 18.6 percent in the first quarter compared to 1996, a Finance Ministry report said.

- Work inspectors have discovered thousands of banking employees performing illegal temporary work. The worst cases were found at Banco Comercial Portugues (BCP), Banco Espirito Santo and Banco Totta & Acores.

- Banks and insurance companies will not get money from the European social fund since it now favours small and medium companies. Only companies which offer professional training in priority areas will be considered.

- The opposition Social Democrat Party will launch a parliamentary inquiry into Prime Minister Antonio Guterres's role in the granting of a state-guaranteed loan to the General Workers Union (UGT) which has traditional links to the ruling Socialist Party.

- The first phase of Electricidade de Portugal-EDP's privatisation will involve the selling of 600 million shares, representing 30 percent of capital, and the state will receive 500 billion escudos from the operation, EDP president Antonio de Almeida said.
- State airline TAP, Caixa Geral de Depositos and the state's OGMA, a company which repairs planes, will form a consortium to bid in the privatisation of Mozambique airlines LAM.

- The chairman of the BCP banking group Jardim Goncalves is considering selling the group's 20 percent stake in insurance company Mundial Confianca, but this will depend on how the insurer performs on the stock market.
